questions.text: A diagnosis of retinal detachment is made in a patient who presented with the complaint of sudden painless loss of vision. A senior resident shows Shaffer's sign to all the interns, which is seen in this patient. As you were one of the interns, you were shown _________

choices.text: Presence of shifting fluid in superonasal retinal breaks
Presence of shifting fluid in superotemporal retinal breaks
Presence of pigment cells in posterior vitreous
Presence of pigment cells in anterior vitreous

questions.solution:
Shaffer’s sign seen on slit-lamp examination refers to the presence of pigment cells in anterior vitreous in the case of rhegmatous retinal detachment.

It is also known as tobacco dusting.

Retinal detachment is the result of the accumulation of fluid between the retina and the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE).

Retinal detachment is classified into the following:

  • Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment: Fluid accumulates after a break (tear) occurs in the retina.
  • Tractional retinal detachment: Fibro-vascular membranes in the vitreous due to long-standing vitreous hemorrhage exert traction on the retina.
  • Exudative retinal detachment: Exudative fluid from the choroid, collects in the subretinal space, leading to retinal detachment.

Note:

Shifting fluid sign is seen in serous or exudative retinal detachment.

In serous retinal detachment, there is a subretinal accumulation of the serous fluid mostly due to the breakdown in the blood-retinal barrier. When the position of the head is altered, the fluid shifts to the dependent portion.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old diabetic woman presents with painless loss of vision. The ocular findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is true about this condition?
  1. Painless progressive loss of vision
  2. Iris shadow is absent
  3. Visual acuity does not improve on pin-hole testing
  4. Black spots against red glow on distant direct ophthalmoscopy
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the above image are suggestive of an immature senile cataract. Here, iris shadows are present on examination.

An immature senile cataract is characterized by partial opacification of the lens. The cuneiform and cupuliform patterns of opacification may be seen which later become diffuse and irregular. The lens appears greyish-white. Both immature senile cataract and nuclear sclerosis without cataract present with painless progressive loss of vision and appear grey in color on oblique illumination examination. They can be differentiated based on the following points:

  Immature senile cataract Nuclear sclerosis
Iris shadow Present Absent

Distant direct ophthalmoscopy

Black spots against red glow are observed

No black spots are seen against the red glow

Slit-lamp examination

Areas of cataractous cortex seen

Clear lens with nuclear sclerosis seen

Visual acuity on pin-hole testing

Does not improve

Usually improves

 

Related Pearl: Maturation of Cortical Cataract

1. Stage of lamellar separation 

2. Stage of incipient cataract- cuneiform and cupuliform patterns can be made out at this stage.

 

3. Immature senile cataract: 

  • The lens is greyish white.
  • Clear cortex is still present, so iris shadow is visible
  • Untreated immature cataracts can progress and develop into intumescent cataracts as a result of swelling and congestion of the lens due to degeneration of lens proteins.

 

4. Mature cortical cataract/ Ripe cataract 

  • The opacification is complete
  • The lens is pearly white

 

 

5. Morgagnian hypermature cataract

  • The whole cortex liquefies and the lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid.
  • The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, altering its position with a change in the position of the head.

questions.text:
At an eye camp, a 75-year-old man, who is a chronic smoker and has hypertension and a BMI of 35 kg/m2, presents with complaints of diminishing vision over the past 25 years in the right eye. His visual acuity is 6/36, and the anterior segment appears normal. The OCT image obtained is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

OCT- Optical coherence tomography
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with the OCT image showing drusen are suggestive of dry or non-exudative age-related macular degeneration (AMD). Drusen are the earliest visible clinical signs of AMD. They are composed of lipids, amyloid, complement factors, and associated cellular components.

Age-related macular degeneration (AMD), a degenerative disorder of the macula, is characterized by the presence of drusen and retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) changes. It is the most common cause of permanent central vision loss in the elderly.

Risk factors:
  • Age
  • White race
  • Family history
  • Smoking
  • Hypertension
  • Cardiovascular diseases
  • Obesity
  • Aspirin intake 

There are two types of ARMD:

  • Dry AMD (non-exudative, non-neovascular) is the most common form, comprising around 90% of the diagnosed cases. It is initially characterized by macular drusens, which later progresses to geographical atrophy. Geographic atrophy (GA) is the advanced stage of dry AMD. 
  • Wet AMD (exudative, neovascular) is much less common than the dry type, but it is associated with more rapid progression to advanced sight loss. It presents with painless progressive visual loss over months, central scotoma, and the fundoscopy showing sub-retinal hemorrhage near the macula (Option D).

Treatment:

Dry AMD: No effective treatment is available. Antioxidants like lutein and zeaxanthin are given as prophylaxis.

Wet AMD: Treatment depends on the location of the choroidal neovascularization membrane.

  • For extrafoveal membrane – laser photocoagulation
  • For subfoveal and juxta foveal treatment options are as follows:
    • Intravitreal injection of anti-VEGF
    • Photodynamic therapy – dye used is verteporfin followed by exposure to light from the diode
    • Transpupillary thermotherapy

The image below shows drusens in the macular area in dry macular degeneration:

Option A: Cystoid macular edema (CME) is a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform (Henle's layer) and an inner nuclear layer of the retina. This results in the formation of cyst-like cavities around the foveola. Patients may complain of blurring, distortion, and micropsia. In clinically established cases, the macula will show a 'honeycomb' appearance on ophthalmoscopy due to multiple cystoid spaces. Optical coherence tomography image shows intraretinal cystoid spaces and foveal depression. In advanced cases, a lamellar macular hole may develop.

Given below is an OCT image showing intraretinal cystoid spaces in CME:

Option B: Macular hole is a partial or full-thickness hole in the neurosensory retina of the foveal region. It could be idiopathic or caused due to trauma or CME. There is a decrease in vision, typically around 6/60 for full-thickness holes. FFA shows early foveal hyper fluorescence without a leak.

The OCT image of the macular hole is given below, which shows a full-thickness hole in the foveal retina:

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presented with progressive, painless loss of vision in the right eye. There was no history of associated photopsia. On examination, a shifting fluid sign is present. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the presence of shifting fluid is suggestive of exudative retinal detachment (ED). 

Exudative RD is characterized by the accumulation of fluid beneath the retina in the absence of a retinal break or traction. Fluid leaks outside the vessels and accumulates under the retina. RD does not occur as long as the retinal pigment epithelium is pumping the leaking fluid into the choroidal circulation. 

Causes:

  • Inflammatory conditions like choroiditis, posterior scleritis
  • Choroidal tumors like melanoma
  • Toxemia of pregnancy
  • Central serous retinopathy
  • Coats disease

Patients may present with painless progressive visual field defects without photopsia. Floaters may be present if there is an associated vitritis.

Clinical signs include

  • Convex configuration of the retinal detachment, with a smooth surface
  • A detached retina is very mobile
  • Shifting fluid sign - Subretinal fluid causes detachment of the retinal portion under which it accumulates. In the upright position, the fluid collects under the inferior retina. But in the supine position, the inferior retina flattens and the fluid shifts posteriorly, which leads to detachment of the superior retina.
  • The cause of the RD may be apparent. 
  • Leopard spots - Scattered areas of clumped subretinal pigment may be seen after the detachment has flattened.

Retinal detachment (RD) is the result of the accumulation of fluid between the retina and the retinal pigment epithelium. It is classified into the following:

  • Rhegmatogenous RD - due to a tear or break in the retina
  • Secondary RD - due to some other preceding event
    • Exudative RD
    • Tractional RD

The image shows the shifting fluid sign and late-phase fluorescein angiogram showing hyperfluorescent spots with a leopard spot pattern in the posterior fundus and staining of the arteries and an avascular area in the nasal region, respectively.

Other options:

Option A: Breaks in the Descemet membrane may occur due to

  • Corneal enlargement in infantile glaucoma. Haab striae are horizontal concentric lines representing the breaks in Descemet’s membrane, seen in patients with congenital glaucoma.
  • Deformations such as keratoconus
  • Birth trauma

The image below shows Haab's striae. 

Option B -  Rhegmatogenous RD: In this condition, fluid accumulates after a break (tear) occurs in the retina. The most dangerous type of retinal break is a horseshoe tear. The most dangerous location of the retinal break is the superior temporal retina. Risk factors for the development of rhegmatogenous RD are:

  • High myopia
  • Blunt trauma
  • Previous cataract surgery (aphakia and pseudophakia)
  • Lattice degeneration of the retina

Clinical features of rhegmatogenous RD:

  • Symptoms
    • Photopsia: Flashes of light due to vitreoretinal traction at the site of the break. Photopsia is symptom-specific for rhegmatogenous detachment. 
    • Floaters: Due to associated vitreous haemorrhage
    • Visual field defect: A black curtain/veil in front of the eye
  • Signs
    • Shaffer's sign: Pigments in the anterior vitreous (tobacco dusting) are a feature of fresh retinal detachment.
    • The detached retina is convex in its configuration.
    • The surface is corrugated with undulations.

Option C - Tractional RD: It occurs when the vitreous has an abnormally strong attachment to the retina. With vitreous liquefaction and subsequent contraction, the retina is pulled away from the retinal pigment epithelium without a retinal break.

  • Causes
    • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
    • Retinopathy of prematurity
    • Eales' disease
  • Signs
    • The detached retina is concave in its configuration.
    • No breaks are seen.

The image below shows the tractional segments and bands with a concave retina.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man after his retirement party came with the complaint of sudden painless loss of vision in his left eye for the past 2 hours. The fundoscopic examination picture shows a Hollenhorst plaque as shown below.  Which of the other following fundoscopic findings does not align with the diagnosis?

choices.text: Milky white appearance of the retina
Cattle-trucking is seen in the retinal vessels
Cherry red spot at the centre of the macula

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of sudden painless loss of vision with the presence of a Hollenhorst plaque is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). Direct pupillary reflex is absent in these cases; hence, it does not align with the diagnosis.

Retinal artery occlusion can occur due to emboli from the carotids, atherosclerosis-related thrombosis, retinal arteritis, raised intraocular pressure, etc. Emboli are the most common cause. They may be:

  • Cholestrol emboli or Hollenhorst plaque- at retinal vessel bifurcation, from carotid artery atheromas
  • Calcium emboli from cardiac valves
  • Platelet fibrin emboli from carotid atheromas

Patients present with sudden painless loss of vision and may have a past history of transient visual loss (amaurosis fugax). On examination, visual acuity is diminished, the direct pupillary reflex is lost and the relative afferent pupillary defect is positive. On funduscopy, the following findings are seen:

  • Narrowed retinal arteries and veins
  • Milky white appearance of the retina due to oedema (Option B)
  • Cherry red spot at the centre of the macula (Option D)
  • Cattle trucking or segmentation of the blood column in the retinal veins (Option C)

CRAO is treated with immediate lowering of intraocular pressure, intermittent ocular massage, IV mannitol, and IV acetazolamide. Vasodilators like nitroglycerine and oral isosorbide dinitrate are helpful. Steroids for arteritis, fibrinolytic therapy, and laser photodisruption of the embolus may be done.

Related Pearl: Important causes of cherry-red spots

  • Central retinal and cilioretinal artery occlusion

    • GM1 gangliosidosis
    • Mucolipidosis type I (sialidosis)
    • GM2 gangliosidosis (Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff disease)
    • Farber disease
    • Niemann–Pick disease
  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol

questions.text: A  post-cataract surgery patient who had the surgery 3 months back presents with complaints of blurring of vision for the past 2 weeks. On fundoscopy, there is a honeycomb appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a post-cataract surgery patient presenting with a blurring of vision and a honeycomb appearance on fundoscopy is suggestive of cystoid macular edema (CME).

Common causes of CME include previous cataract surgery, uveitis, central retinal vein occlusions, diabetic retinopathy, retinitis pigmentosa, retinopathy of prematurity, and topical prostaglandins. Cystoid macular edema in post-cataract surgery patients is termed as Irvine-Gass syndrome. 

In CME, optical coherence tomography (OCT) shows loss of foveal depression, intraretinal cystoid spaces, and retinal thickening. CME occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier. Due to retinal vessel leak fluid or exudate comes out and forms cystic space in the central retina. Mostly it gets accumulated in the outer plexiform (Henle's layer) and inner nuclear layers of the retina. 

On fundoscopy, the multiple cystoid oval spaces in CME appear as a  honeycomb appearance. In Fundus fluorescein angiography fluid accumulation in the outer plexiform, layer shows a characteristic flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance) as shown below:

Topical antiprostaglandins and steroids are used in the management of CME. 

Other options:

Option B- Macular hole is the partial or full-thickness hole in the neurosensory retina. An OCT image of a full-thickness macular hole is shown below:

Option C- Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of the neuroretina in the macular region with or without retinal pigment epithelium detachment.

Due to the altered permeability of the choroidal vascular system, there is an increase in the tissue hydrostatic pressure in the choroid. This causes a breach in the outer blood-retinal barrier. Leakage of fluid across this area causes detachment of the neurosensory retina. An OCT of central serous retinopathy showing neurosensory retinal detachment from the retinal pigment epithelium is given below:

Option D- Posterior capsular opacification, otherwise known as after cataract/secondary cataract, is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery. It occurs due to the proliferation of lens epithelial cells that have been left out inside the capsular bag after cataract surgery. 

They can present in different patterns such as:

  • Elschnig's pearls: present as vacuolated (pearl-type) grape-like clusters of swollen cells 
  • Soemmering's ring: present as a white annular proliferation that is formed at the periphery of the capsular bag.
  • Fibrosis type: present as fibroblastic metaplasia of the epithelial cells 

A posterior capsulotomy (creating a hole in the posterior capsule) using an Nd: YAG laser is the mainstay of treatment. It is indicated when the patient is symptomatic. 

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with blurring of vision and the presence of a dark spot with distorted vision in his right eye for the past week. He has been taking steroid tablets for asthma. His best corrected visual acuity measured 6/24 in his right eye and 6/6 in his left eye. Posterior segment examination is shown in the image. What is the first-line management for this case?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with visual abnormalities, history of steroid intake, and the fundal image depicting focal fundal detachment are suggestive of central serous retinopathy. Discontinuation of steroid use is the first line of management in this case.

Central serous chorioretinopathy (CSR) is an idiopathic disorder characterized by a localized serous detachment of the sensory retina at the macula.

Recent studies implicate abnormal choroidal circulation as the cause of CSR. 

Risk factors:

  • Age: young adults (20–50 years)
  • Sex: male > female
  • Steroid intake 
  • Emotional stress
  • Pregnancy
  • Cushing's syndrome
  • Hypertension
  • Sleep apnea syndrome

Clinical features:

  • Mostly unilateral
  • Retinal detachment - Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Relative positive scotoma
  • Micropsia
  • Metamorphopsia

Investigations:

  • Ophthalmoscopy - circular ring reflex present and foveal reflex absent
  • FFA - enlarging inkblot pattern or smoke stack pattern
  • OCT - optically empty neurosensory elevation at macular region.

Spontaneous resolution is seen in most cases and hence observation is enough. Steroids are contraindicated. The disease is usually self-limiting but may recur.

Other treatment options for recurrent and chronic cases: Laser photocoagulation, photodynamic therapy, and intravitreal anti-VEGF.

The image below depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), showing an enlarging ink-blot pattern/ enlarging dot sign - A small hyperfluorescent spot that gradually enlarges in size - seen in Central Serous Retinopathy (CSR).

The image below depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), showing smokestack appearance - A small hyperfluorescent spot that ascends vertically like a smokestack that looks like an umbrella or a mushroom - seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR).

 The image below depicts optical coherence tomography (OCT) showing fluid accumulation in the subretinal space, with shallow retinal detachment - seen in CSR.

questions.text: A patient presents with a sudden onset of nausea and pain in his right eye associated with blurring of vision and halos. On examination, ciliary congestion, corneal oedema, and a mid-dilated pupil are observed. Gonioscopy reveals a closed angle of the anterior chamber. All of the following are sequelae to this episode except _____.
questions.solution:
All of the above are sequelae to this episode, except iris bombe as it is implicated in the pathogenesis of angle closure glaucoma, not a sequel.

The clinical vignette of acute onset ocular pain with nausea or vomiting, blurring of vision with halos with ciliary congestion, corneal edema, and a mid-dilated pupil on examination are all indicative of acute angle-closure glaucoma.

It is an ocular emergency that causes acute red-eye and is associated with at least two of the following symptoms: acute onset ocular pain with nausea or vomiting, intermittent blurring of vision with halos, photophobia, or loss of vision.

It is also associated with three of the following signs: ciliary congestion, corneal edema and subsequent haziness, fixed and mid-dilated, usually oval pupil, a shallow anterior chamber, and intraocular pressure elevated above 40 mmHg.

The clinical status of the eye subsequent to an attack of acute angle-closure glaucoma is considered as the sequelae of the attack, regardless of whether the patient has been treated or not. These include:

  1. Post-surgical acute primary angle-closure
  2. Spontaneous angle reopening
  3. Ciliary body shut down
  4. Vogt's triad, which includes glaukomflecken i.e anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity, patches of iris atrophy, and slightly dilated non-reacting pupil.

Iris bombe is not a part of the sequelae of acute angle-closure glaucoma. It refers to the collection of aqueous in the posterior chamber pushing the peripheral flaccid iris anteriorly resulting in appositional angle closure.

The below image shows features of angle closure glaucoma.

The management of acute angle-closure glaucoma includes:

  • Immediate medical management to lower IOP- oral acetazolamide or intravenous mannitol is used first. Tricyclic antidepressants, drugs having significant anticholinergic action should be avoided or used with extreme caution in patients prone to developing acute angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Definitive treatment with laser peripheral iridotomy.
  • Prophylaxis of the fellow eye followed by long-term glaucoma surveillance and management of intraocular pressure of both eyes.

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: A 65-year-old  female patient presented with sudden painless loss of vision. She has had type 2 diabetes mellitus for 12 years. Ophthalmoscopy shows evidence of loss of fundal features, floating debris and a dark red glow. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with sudden, painless vision loss, floating debris and a dark red glow on fundoscopic examination is most likely suffering from vitreous hemorrhage. Image below shows an example depicting the same.

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy, which can arise in people with long-term diabetes mellitus, is a common risk factor for vitrous hemorrhage caused by the breakage of the fragile blood vessels on the retina's surface. Intravitreal blood blocks light from reaching the retina, resulting in patients experiencing sudden onset cloudy vision, sometimes with a red tint, or vision loss.In the Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) classification diabetics with advanced eye disease are likely to manifest with tractional retinal detachment, neovascular glaucoma or persistent vitreous hemorrhage. 

Patients with vitreous hemorrhage can be adequately managed with bed rest to prevent additional bleeding and elevation of the head to promote blood settling away from the vsual axis. Treatment must also be targeted to the underlying cause of the bleed.(eg.photocoagulation for proliferative retinopathy). Vitreoretinal surgery with photocoagulation is indicated in patients with persistent vitreal hemorrhage. Alternatively, pars plana vitrectomy may be deemed necessary in patients with persistent vitreal hemorrhage. 

Vitreous hemorrhage has a variable presentation depending on the severity of the hemorrhage. The mild hemorrhage causes sudden onset floaters and diffuse blurring of vision, but may not affect visual acuity, whilst a dense bleed may result in sudden painless loss of vision.

Causes

  • Acute posterior vitreous detachment associated either with a retinal tear or avulsion of a peripheral vessel
  • Proliferative retinopathy
    • Diabetic
    • Retinal vein occlusion
    • Sickle cell disease
    • Eales disease
    • Vasculitis
  • Miscellaneous retinal disorders
    • Macroaneurysm
    • Telangiectasia
    • Capillary hemangioma
  • Trauma
  • Systemic
    • Bleeding disorders
    • Terson syndrome

Treatment is dictated by severity and cause, but an increasingly low threshold is being adopted for early vitrectomy.

Terson syndrome
Terson syndrome refers to the combination of intraocular and subarachnoid hemorrhage secondary to aneurysmal rupture, most commonly arising from the anterior communicating artery.

The investigation of choice for vitreous hemorrhage is an ultrasound B-scan.

Other options 

Option A - Patients with retinal detachment can develop floaters and have acute vision loss. However, photpsia is common and fundoscopy reveals an elevated retina with folds or tears.

An image showing retinal detachment at the fovea and the macula is shown below.

Option C - Patients with macular degeneration typically have painless central blurring of vision which is progressive as opposed to vitreous hemorrhage which is acute in its presentation. Age related macular degeneration is the most common cause of blindness in developed nations with a preponderance among women. Smoking is an independent risk factor. Hormone replacement therapy, estrogen therapy as well as supplementation of antioxidants and zinc have proven efficacy is retarding its progression.

Image depicting age related macular degeneration with the presence of drusens is as shown below.

Option D - Patients with central retinal vein occlusion can also present with sudden, painless loss of vision but would have scattered, diffuse hemorrhages, disc swelling and cotton wool spots.

Image showing central retinal vein occlusion is as follows.

questions.text: A young male patient is admitted with sudden onset of loss of vision, restricted movements, and severe pain in his right eye, following a penetrating injury. Slit-lamp examination shows a cloudy cornea and pus in the anterior chamber. Visual acuity shows no light perception. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a patient presenting with sudden loss of vision and severe eye pain following a penetrating eye injury, along with features of restricted eye movements, pus in the anterior chamber, and cloudy cornea, is suggestive of panophthalmitis. The treatment of choice for panophthalmitis is evisceration.

In evisceration, the contents of the eyeball are removed, leaving behind the sclera. It is done to avoid the risk of intracranial dissemination of infection. 

Panophthalmitis is an intense purulent inflammation of the entire eyeball, including the Tenon’s capsule. Infection can occur as a result of exogenous penetrating injuries, perforation of corneal ulcers, hematogenous spread of infections, or direct spread of infection from surrounding structures (e.g. orbital cellulitis). 

Clinical features include

  • Severe ocular pain and headache
  • Complete loss of vision
  • Marked redness and swelling of eyes
  • Profuse watering, purulent discharge
  • Constitutional symptoms - fever, malaise

Ocular examination:

  • Vision - no perception of light
  • Lids - edematous, hyperemia
  • Eyeball - proptosis
  • Ocular motility - grossly restricted, painful
  • Conjunctiva - chemosis, congestion
  • Cornea - cloudy, edematous
  • Anterior chamber - hypopyon
  • Intra-ocular pressure - raised

Treatment

  1. Anti-inflammatory drugs and analgesics to relieve pain
  2. Broad-spectrum antibiotics
  3. Evisceration is the definitive surgical procedure and the treatment of choice since it has superior long-term cosmetic outcomes and faster recovery when compared with enucleation.

Other options:

Option B: Enucleation - This procedure involves the removal of the entire eyeball with the major part of the optic nerve, leaving behind the extraocular muscles. It is done in cases of retinoblastoma and malignant melanoma. It can be done with a painful blind eye but evisceration is the treatment of choice.

Option C: Exenteration- This is a mutilating surgery in which all the orbits' contents and periorbita are removed. It is indicated for malignant tumors arising from the orbital structures or spreading from the eyeball.

Option D: Debulking- This procedure is done for the reduction of as much of the bulk (volume) of a tumor as possible. Nowadays, debulking of the orbit is preferred over exenteration.

questions.text: A 70-year-old lady presented with a progressive diminution of central vision in the right eye. On examination, her visual acuity was 6/60 and Amsler's grid test showed central scotoma. Fundus examination revealed the following findings. Which of the following features will be seen if a fundus fluorescein angiography(FFA) is done?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of an elderly female with progressive diminution of central vision, decreased visual acuity (6/60) and amsler's grid test showing central scotoma point towards the diagnosis of macular hole. The fundus showing a full-thickness macular hole with a surrounding cuff of subretinal fluid confirms the diagnosis.

Fundus fluorescein angiography(FFA), shows early foveal hyperfluorescene without a leak. 

Optical coherence tomography (OCT) examination confirms a large full-thickness hole with posterior vitreous detached from the disc and macula.

Macular hole (MH) is a vitreoretinal interface disease characterized by a partial or full-thickness neurosensory retinal defect in the centre of the macula. Females are more commonly involved (F: M=3:1) in their sixth or seventh decade of life. Vitreo-retinal interface abnormality along with its tractional forces plays a major role in the development of macular holes.

Clinical features include decreased vision (typically around 6/60 level for a full-thickness hole and better for a partial hole), metamorphopsia or distortion of vision and central scotoma seen on Amsler's grid.

Watzke-Allen test- A thin line of light is projected over the macula with a slit lamp and the patient is asked to report on its appearance. A line appearing broken may indicate a macular hole.

Early stages do not require any treatment as spontaneous hole closure can occur. Advanced stages can be treated with pars plana vitrectomy with posterior hyaloid removal and internal limiting membrane peeling.

Other options:

Option A: Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of the macular region neurosensory retina with/without retinal pigment epithelium detachment. FFA shows two patterns of leakage, ink-blot pattern and smoke-stack pattern.

Option B: Cystoid macular edema is defined as a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform (Henle's layer) and an inner nuclear layer of the retina. FFA shows a flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance).

Option D: Age-related Macular degeneration (ARMD) also known as senile macular degeneration is a chronic and progressive bilateral degenerative disorder of the macula that affects older individuals >50 yrs. The below given FFA image below shows stars in sky appearance of Drusen.

questions.text:
A patient comes with complaints of frequent changes in her presbyopic glasses. On gonioscopy, the anterior chamber angle appears normal. Perimetry shows a small wing-shaped paracentral scotoma. IOP is measured to be 23mmHg. What is the likely diagnosis?

IOP - Intraocular pressure
questions.solution:
A history of frequent changes of presbyopic glasses with an increased IOP and paracentral scotoma suggests a likely diagnosis of primary open-angle glaucoma.

Primary open-angle glaucoma/chronic simple glaucoma occurs due to reduced aqueous outflow facility which is caused by trabecular meshwork stiffening. It is characterized by open anterior chamber angle, characteristic optic disc cupping, specific visual field defects, and a slowly progressive increase of IOP.  

Symptoms such as new-onset headache/eye ache are present. However, patients most commonly present with frequent changes in presbyopic glasses.

The optic disc changes are progressive with an increasing cup: disc (C/D) ratio (normal is 0.3 to 0.4), nasal shifting of retinal vessels (Bayonetting sign), and finally resulting in glaucomatous optic atrophy where the optic disc appears excavated. Visual field defects, such as small wing-shaped paracentral scotoma, is the earliest clinically significant scotoma. 

Tonometry and central corneal thickness measurement should be done to correctly measure IOP. Normal IOP ranges from 11- 21mmHg. To rule out other glaucomas gonioscopy is done. Visual field defects are detected by perimetry.

Medical therapy such as prostaglandin analogs, topical beta-blockers, etc are used in treatment. Laser trabeculoplasty and trabeculotomy can be required if it is not managed medically.

Other options:

Option A: Primary angle-closure glaucoma occurs due to slow synechiae closure of the anterior chamber angle. Otherwise, other presentations are similar to open-angle glaucoma with optic disc cupping and visual field defects. 

Option C: Ocular hypertension is defined as a persistent increase of IOP without optic disc changes and visual field defects. 

Option D: Normal-tension glaucoma occurs when the IOP is normal and below 21mmHg, but there is typical glaucomatous change and visual field defects.

Related Pearl: Visual field Defects in Open-Angle Glaucoma

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with progressively worsening pain, redness in the right eye for the last two days. She has a history of sarcoidosis. On examination, the right eye is inflamed around the cornea, the pupil is constricted, and reacts sluggishly to light. The iris appears muddy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with progressively worsening eye pain and redness, constricted pupil reacting sluggishly to light, muddy iris, and a history of sarcoidosis is likely to have anterior uveitis. 

Sarcoidosis is a systemic inflammatory disorder characterized by the formation of non-caseating granulomas. Anterior uveitis is often a presenting symptom of sarcoidosis.

Anterior uveitis presents with blurred vision, pain, photophobia, circumcorneal conjunctival injection (around the limbus) with an aqueous flare and keratin precipitates. The pupil is constricted and reacts sluggishly to light. The clear pattern of the iris is lost and it appears muddy.

Slit-lamp examination shows the following signs in anterior uveitis:

Corneal signs: 

  • Keratic precipitates

Anterior chamber signs: 

  • Hypopyon
  • Aqueous cells
  • Aqueous flare
  • Deep and irregular anterior chamber due to posterior synechiae

Iris signs: 

  • Loss of normal pattern
  • Change in color "muddy iris"
  • Posterior synechiae

Pupillary signs: 

  • Constricted pupil
  • Irregular pupil shape
  • Ectropion of uveal pigment
  • Occlusion pupillae - blocked pupil due to extensive exudate

Steroids and cycloplegics are the mainstay of management for uveitis.

Cycloplegics

  • atropine
  • Relieves spasm of iris sphincter and ciliary muscle
  • Prevents the formation of synechiae

Steroids reduce inflammation by their anti-inflammatory effect 

Systemic therapy 

  • Steroids
  • NSAIDs
  • Immunosuppressants
    • Used in severe cases

Other options:

Option A: Acute bacterial conjunctivitis presents with pain, irritation, photophobia with hyperemia (pink eye), and purulent exudate. There is a diffuse conjunctival injection which is less seen in the circum-corneal region (as opposed to anterior uveitis)

Option C: Endophthalmitis is the infection of the intra-ocular cavities which presents with severe pain, loss of vision, and lid edema. It is usually seen in post-operative cases of ocular trauma (exogenous) and patients hospitalized with severe bacterial, viral, or fungal infections (endogenous).

Option D: Acute primary angle-closure glaucoma presents with severe unilateral eye pain, associated with headache and loss of vision. The examination shows a red congested eye, corneal edema with a shallow anterior chamber, and a mid-dilated pupil.

questions.text: You suspect non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy and advise Fundus fluorescein angiography(FFA) in a 50-year-old hypertensive male patient, who presented with the following visual field defect. Presence of which of the following finding in FFA would help you to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fundus fluorescein angiography in a patient with non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy would reveal delayed disc filling.

Altitudinal hemianopia is defined as hemianopia affecting the upper or lower half of the visual field. The above image depicts altitudinal hemianopia ( involving lower half of the visual field), which is present in both arteritic and non-arteritic ischemic optic neuropathy.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man developed a painless diminution of vision in his right eye 6 months ago but did not seek medical attention. Two weeks ago, he started to notice mild blurring in his left eye and has now come for evaluation. According to him, his elder brother and maternal uncle also had similar vision problems. Which fundus finding would point towards Leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy in this patient?

choices.text: Hyperemic optic disc with telangiectatic capillaries

questions.solution:
Hyperemic optic disc with telangiectatic capillaries would be suggestive of LHON.  

LHON is related to a mitochondrial DNA mutation. This results in impaired mitochondrial adenosine triphosphate production, which affects the highly energy-dependent optic nerve.  

In the acute phase, the optic disc is hyperemic and swollen with telangiectatic capillaries. However, the optic disc does not leak on fluorescein angiography. Later stages may show primary optic atrophy.

Match the following visual field defects with the likely site of the lesion:
  1. Right superior homonymous quadrantanopia
  2. Right-sided homonymous hemianopia
  3. Right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing
  4. Right inferior quadrantic hemianopia
  5. Left-sided complete anopia
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-C, 2-B, 3-E, 4-D, 5-A.

Lesion site Fibers affected Visual defect
A - Left optic nerve Left nasal,

Left temporal fibers 		 5. Left-sided complete anopia
B - Left optic tract Left temporal,

Right nasal fibers		 2. Right-sided homonymous hemianopia
C - Left Meyer's loop Left inferior temporal,

Right inferior nasal fibers 

1. Right superior homonymous  quadrantanopia

(Pie in the sky) 
D -Left Baum's loop Left superior temporal,

Right superior nasal fibers		 4. Right inferior homonymous quadrantanopia 

(Pie in the floor)
E -Left visual cortex sparing the macula Left temporal,

Right nasal fibers, except the macular fibers		 3. Right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing

 

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: A farmer presents with a progressive blurring of vision in his left eye. He said that a branch of a plant injured his eye 1 week ago while working in his field. On examination, an ulcer is seen in his cornea with feathery margins. Microscopy of the ulcer scraping showed branched septate hyphae. He was started on natamycin 5% eye drops. Which adjuvant drug can be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a fungal corneal ulcer. The adjuvant drug that can be given to this patient is atropine sulfate eye drops.

Fungal corneal ulcers are usually caused due to injury to the eye with vegetable matter. The signs are more pronounced but the symptoms are mild. 

Examination findings include:

  • Dry-looking ulcer with feathery margins
  • Sterile circular corneal infiltrates - Wessely's immune ring due to the deposition of immune complexes
  • Satellite lesions
  • Thick, non-sterile hypopyon

Specific treatment of fungal corneal ulcer:

  • Topical drugs: Natamycin, voriconazole, or amphotericin B drops against Aspergillus and Fusarium and nystatin against Candida.
  • Systemic drugs: Oral ketoconazole or voriconazole for ulcers that are severe with hypopyon, perforated, or with suspicion of endophthalmitis.

Non-specific supportive treatment:

  • Atropine (1%) drops or ointment should be instilled in the affected eye two or three times a day to prevent complications like ciliary spasm posterior synechiae formation.
  • Local heat

Steroids are contraindicated in the treatment of fungal corneal ulcers because fungi, which are usually symbiotic saprophytes under normal conditions, become facultative pathogens in the presence of steroids and can cause perforation.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with complaints of eye ache and decreasing vision in his left eye. He underwent phacoemulsification with intraocular lens implantation in the same eye 2 days back. Examination of his left eye appears as shown in the image given below. A slit lamp examination revealed cells and flares in the anterior chamber. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the image showing inflammation of the eyeball and hypopyon, in a patient 2 days after cataract surgery is suggestive of acute postoperative endophthalmitis.

Endophthalmitis is defined as an intraocular inflammation, which predominantly affects the inner spaces of the eye and their contents, i.e., the vitreous and/or the anterior chamber. Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common organism involved in pathogenesis.

Clinically, patients present with symptoms of pain, swelling of the eyelid, decrease in vision 48 to 72 hours after surgery.

Signs include conjunctival chemosis, corneal edema and haziness, and hypopyon due to the pouring of exudates in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber, and posterior chamber.

Slit-lamp examination usually reveals white blood cells (cells) and protein (flare) within the anterior chamber. The diagnosis is confirmed by positive aqueous or vitreous culture.

Intravitreal injections of antibiotics like ceftazidime and vancomycin should be administered immediately after culture specimens have been obtained. Other treatments include:

  • Topical antibiotic
  • Topical mydriatics and cycloplegics
  • Oral steroids
  • Pars plana vitrectomy.

Other options:

Option A: Toxic anterior segment syndrome (TASS) is a sterile postoperative inflammation of the anterior segment caused by either the ethylene gas used for sterilizing intraocular lens (in early cases) or by the lens material (in late cases). It is characterized by increased intraocular pressure, no hypopyon, and no vitreal inflammation. It responds well to steroids.

Option B: Anterior scleritis is characterized by edema and inflammation of the sclera and is more commonly associated with autoimmune conditions.

Option C: Posterior capsular opacification also called after cataract, is the opacification that follows extracapsular extraction of the lens. It occurs due to the proliferation of lens particles left over from surgery.

The illustration given below shows different types of after-cataract.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: For a patient presenting with gradual, painless diminution of vision, the differential diagnosis would not include _________.
questions.solution:
Methyl alcohol amblyopia causes sudden painless diminution of vision.

It is a toxic neuropathy of the optic nerve.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient came with complaints of a sudden decreased vision in both eyes and pain while moving his eyeballs. On examination, vision in both eyes is 3/60. He finds it difficult to read Ishihara’s chart.  Fundus examination showed normal discs and vessels. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of retrobulbar neuritis. The normal optic disc is an important pointer toward retrobulbar neuritis.

Optic neuritis is of three types, based on the appearance of optic disc on fundoscopy:

  • Retrobulbar neuritis - Normal optic disc because optic nerve head is not involved.
  • Papillitis - Hyperemic and edematous disc with peripapillary flame-shaped hemorrhages.
  • Neuroretinitis - Macular star appearance due to involvement of nerve fiber layer (NFL)

The clinical features of retrobulbar neuritis include sudden painful vision loss, decreased color contrast sensitivity, Marcus Gunn pupil and pain on movement of eyeballs.

Demyelinating disorders like multiple sclerosis are the most common cause of retrobulbar neuritis.

Steroids are the mainstay of treatment for such demyelinating causes.

Option A: Eale's disease is characterized by recurrent vitreous hemorrhages. Due to this, the fundoscopic findings will not be normal. It is a type of hypersensitivity reaction to tubercular proteins. This causes periphlebitis leading to hemorrhages.

Option B: Papilloedema is swelling of the optic nerve head due to raised intracranial pressure (ICP). Here also the optic disc would not be normal. The patient will have symptoms of raised ICP such as headache, nausea, deterioration of consciousness, etc.

Option D: Papillitis will have an abnormal optic disc as described above.
